content.intro:
Santo Domingo, an elite destination in the Caribbean, with a beautiful historical centre and stunning beaches, provides the backdrop to the laidback lifestyle of the naturally cheerful Dominicans.

A quintessential destination for sun and beaches, this Garden of Eden is sure to make you move to the catchy, swaying rhythms of bachata, a music and dance that originated here. The city cultivates an irresistible lifestyle in the sun, accented by the fragrance of exotic amber rum and coffee. In 1492, the island of Hispaniola, mysterious and untamed, made an impression on Columbus during his stopover here on his quest for gold. He chose this spot to become the cradle of the New World. Tourism has boomed here since the beginning of the 21st century, with resorts in Punta Cana, Bayahibe, Bavaro, and elsewhere along the white sands of the east coast, but this beautiful island in the tropics has been able to defend its historical identity, as well. Santo Domingo is hidden behind thick walls and has a colonial centre full of rich historical references, such as Spanish Renaissance monasteries, museums, and palaces.
This green paradise has a rich environmental heritage, as well, and fights with vigilance to preserve the lush forests, national parks, and ecosystems that are admired as the ultimate reference of paradise lost. You can still find vast areas of wild beauty and nature sanctuaries of all types. Anchored on a coral reef, the heavenly beaches you will find here are lined with palms waving their fronds at the turquoise horizon. In the province of Samana, the enchanting Rincon has continued for years to be counted among the top ten most beautiful beaches in the world.
Inland, rural areas fulfil an agricultural destiny, simple and rough around the edges, but still cheerful. Made languid by the warmth of the trade winds, shacks brushed with Caribbean pastels coexist with centuries-old coffee plantations dotting the hills. One still lives here as in the 19th century, without water or electricity, waiting for the benefits of fair-trade efforts. Unpredictable and captivating, and a delightful oasis for stressed urban dwellers, Santo Domingo symbolises the ultimate stop, where your secret dreams of conquest and adventure can take refuge.

map.mapTitle: Our selection of must-see places in and around Santo Domingo

weather.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Santo Domingo

airports.title: Santo Domingo Las Américas International Airport

content.title: Explore modernised Dominican cuisine at Buche Perico

introduction.small: Buche Perico pays tribute to Dominican gastronomy in one of the city's old foundries.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Explore modernised Dominican cuisine at Buche Perico

paragraphs.text:
Seating on a bench, a man is reading the papers as, by his feet, another one is shining his shoes. These metallic characters illustrate daily life in Santo Domingo, and also remind visitors that this huge colonial-style building was once the island's first foundry. Now a restaurant, the place has retained its huge oven, as a testimony of another time period. Traditional touches therefore find their way into a much more modern ensemble setting.
Buche Perico spreads under the magnificent glasshouse that lights up when night falls. In one corner, a spectacular lamp hangs over the bar in peaceful harmony, drawing inspiration from the stained-glass windows often found over the thresholds of townhouses of yesteryear. The restaurant looks Dominican and it certainly tastes like it: fish ceviche with coconut and coriander, fresh tuna from Ocoa served with saffron risotto, or the Buche Perico itself, a corn cream and sausage stew typical from Moca, for a gastronomical journey across country.

Buche Perico
Calle El Conde 53
Santo Domingo 10210

+1 809 686 0129

www.bucheperico.com

Menu: around 1,100 DOP

content.title: Casas del XVI, welcome to the Spanish colonial nobility

introduction.small: In the heart of Santo Domingo's Colonial City, listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, these five-century-old houses will take you back to the past.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casas del XVI, welcome to the Spanish colonial nobility

paragraphs.text:
In the name “Casas del XVI”, the Roman numerals remind us of the area's illustrious architectural past. In Santo Domingo, this boutique hotel consists of five colonial houses that are a half-millennium old. A total of 15 rooms reflect the spirit of Spanish nobility in the olden days, as it used to spend time in the city, then considered the gateway to the New World.
Decorated in an identical way, the colourful casas are adorned with local art objects and typical ancient knick-knacks of Dominican Republic. Old tiles, Renaissance-era roofs… many elements have been carefully retained and renovated, and the hotel is wholly integrated into the Colonial City (Ciudad Colonial), listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site. Besides its aristocratic demeanour, Casas del XVI offers high-end services. Each house is run by a butler, at your service everywhere, from your room to the mango-tree-lined patio, for a truly royal experience.

Casas del XVI
Calle Padre Billini No. 252
Santo Domingo 10210

+1 809 688 4061

www.casasdelxvi.net ﻿

Rooms: from 14,264 DOP

content.title: Los Tres Ojos, in the eyes of Santo Domingo

introduction.small: Thousands of years ago, the separation of an ancient lake, provoked by an earthquake, caused the impressive limestone formations in Santo Domingo.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Los Tres Ojos, in the eyes of Santo Domingo

paragraphs.text:
A protected site since 1972, Los Tres Ojos National Park is comprised of three lagoons of clear water that, under the rock of the caves that house them, are coloured with a myriad of shimmering lights. Fed by the Brujuela underground river, these small caverns were once used in the religious ceremonies of the Tainos, a Native American tribe that occupied the West Indies before the arrival of Europeans in the 15th century. Since then, stalactites and stalagmites have been reigning supreme among the park's rock formations.

Discovered in 1916, the three lakes are accessible by modest boats. The sulphurous waters of Aguas Azufradas are rich in calcium and minerals, the Nevera protects you from the surrounding heat, and the Lago de las Mujeres provides refreshment. Beyond its geological wonders, the national park has an abundance of exotic flora and fauna.

Parque Nacional Los Tres Ojos
Avenida de Las Americas
Santo Domingo 11604

+1 809 788 7056

content.title: Sublime Samana: a romantic one-on-one with the ocean

introduction.small: A luxurious pause in a tropical garden, one of the most recent ‘Small Luxury Hotels of the World' is just a 90-minute drive from the capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sublime Samana: a romantic one-on-one with the ocean

paragraphs.text:
Opt for the picturesque spiral staircase to make your grand entrance as it offers direct access to the heart of the restaurant, an underground limestone dome, overlooking a forest of stalactites and stalagmites. (Another entrance exists on avenida Mirador Sur, complete with an elevator). Although bands perform on the outdoor patio, where cigar lovers like to meet, the atmosphere is classy, even somewhat solemn, as is the service. But the gourmet cuisine of Chef Luis Peralta remains one of the prides of the city for its modern ‘Dominican fusion' style. The menu is international and brings together the sound values of French and Spanish cuisine, skilfully combined with local products and exotic spices. Among the classics are the squid fritters Italian style, the veal escalope with lemon and white wine, as well as the much popular seafood stew.

Sublime Samana
Bahía de Coson
Ramal Viva
Las Terrenas 32000
+1 809 240 5050

www.sublimesamana.com

Rooms: from 19,841 DOP

content.title: Club Med: the legendary vacation club

introduction.small: Since 1976, located on the sands of Santo Domingo, the pioneer of the all-in vacation shows its new vision of exclusive luxury.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Club Med: the legendary vacation club

paragraphs.text:
This founder of the ‘all-inclusive vacation' offers original options conceived of to satisfy all demands. Enjoy the sumptuous 70-square-metre family suites in the ‘5 Trident Luxury Space', or relax in the new ‘Zen Oasis' area, a village within the village reserved for adults.

Without leaving behind the conviviality that built their legend, Club Med has created a cocooning space, with its own beach, where you can relax and rejuvenate. All rooms feature a private garden or terrace that opens onto the pool and lounge bar. Close by, the L'Occitane Spa promises a wellness retreat. As for the space ‘Creactive by Cirque du Soleil', it aims to be a dreamlike playground to teach the circus arts. Your only problem will be choosing between yoga palapa, installed facing the horizon, the call to idleness, or the bubbles of a Jacuzzi tub.

Club Med Punta Cana
Apt Postal 106 Higuey
23 000 Punta Cana

+1 809 686 5500

www.clubmed.com

Package: from 68,826 DOP for 7 nights

content.title: Parque Nacional Los Haitises

introduction.small: Get on board at Sabana de la Mar to venture into this vegetation labyrinth, much of which remains untouched by human presence.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Parque Nacional Los Haitises

paragraphs.text:
North of the peninsula of Samana, this nature reserve is a remarkable biodiversity area, where dense forests and deep fjords are lost in the mangroves. The presence of a guide is indispensable and allows you to move about this prehistoric, subtropical universe. Since the Miocene era, the ground has been regularly soaked with frequent rain. This has allowed for the creation of narrow inland stretches of sea, resistant to any embarkation.

On the bird island you will have the chance to observe many animal species, some threatened by extinction: you could catch a glimpse of the magnificent frigate bird with its striking red chest and brown-black feathers or one of many pelicans. They find refuge in this rainforest, which contains valuable tree species, such as cedar and mahogany. Try to visit the underground cavern network, which has nearly 1,000 caves, some of which are still unexplored. On the walls of the Angel and San Gabriel caves, vast as cathedrals, you will see remarkable pre-Columbian petro glyphs, made by Taino Native Americans, who have survived the centuries.

Parque Nacional Los Haitises
Province de Samana 32000

+1 809 720 6035

content.title: La Renaissance Jaragua Hotel & Casino: favourite of night owls

introduction.small: If most hotels in the capital have a club and a casino, the bar of the Jaragua deserves a detour for its party atmosphere, shows, and musicians.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Renaissance Jaragua Hotel & Casino: favourite of night owls

paragraphs.text:
On the Malecon, the promenade on the seaside, the massive silhouette of the Jaragua stands out. A rallying point for nights on the town, the thriving scene here competes head-on with the neon lights of Las Vegas. In 1990, the bar proudly entered into the history of cinema when it served as the main backdrop for Robert Redford during the filming of Havana, directed by Sydney Pollack.

The highlight is weekend evenings, which attract regulars in gala dress, with white suits and panama hats. And, as music and dance go hand in hand in the lives of Dominicans, come for the waltz, merengue, and bachata. On stage, you may see a big band playing updated swing music, popular in the 1940s, with sax, trumpet, and trombone out in force; it's a real treat for fans of Glenn Miller and Count Basie's music, spiced up with a little tropical sauce.

Le Renaissance Jaragua Hotel & Casino
Av. George Washington
Santo Domingo, 10210

+1 809 221 2222

www.marriott.com/hotels/travel/sdqgw-renaissance-santo-domingo-jaragua-hotel-and-casino/

Menu: around 250 DOP

content.title: Pat'e Palo European Brasserie: pause on the Plaza de Espana

introduction.small: In a historical building with a pleasant terrace and a bodega, this typical address is appreciated by both the Dominican bourgeoisie and visitors.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pat'e Palo European Brasserie: pause on the Plaza de Espana

paragraphs.text:
With a splendid view of the Alcazar de Colon, the most visited monument in Santo Domingo, this lively restaurant deserves its ranking among the best spots in the Zona Colonial. During the day, you can come in for lunch or a break between museum visits, or, for the ultimate pleasure, have dinner under the stars, with the cheerful servers dressed as pirates, in homage to the restaurant's namesake. A successful enterprise with an attractive brasserie menu and a mission to be ultra-selective in the choice of its products, the Palo Pat'e is often overflowing with clients. Cuisines range across the great standards of French, Latin, and Creole dishes but also integrate the chef's training in Asian specialties. You can find everything from a squid ink risotto to a triple cheeseburger with grilled onions and the eastern style salmon tartare with caramelised sesame. Do not miss the tastes of the island with the unusual chocolate truffle with rum, tobacco aroma, and Dominican coffee.

Pat'e Palo European Brasserie
Plaza Espana
Ciudad Colonial
Santo Domingo 10210

+1 809 687 8089

www.patepalo.com

Menu: from 1,587 DOP

content.title: Calle El Conde: a favourite walk for Dominicans

introduction.small: Named after Conde de Peñalba, governor of Hispaniola in 1655, this pedestrian street concentrates all of the energy of downtown Santo Domingo.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Calle El Conde: a favourite walk for Dominicans

paragraphs.text:
With a dense concentration of shops and art galleries, Calle El Conde is a tourist destination in and of itself. You can find almost everything here, from antiques to souvenirs, handicrafts to CDs, and, of course, panama hats. Munch on a banana fritter to recover from your shopping, or take a seat on a terrace to immerse yourself in the local atmosphere and mix with the Dominicans, known for their warmth and kindness. The motley crowd sauntering along on the cobblestone street is a spectacle in itself, accompanied by exotic rhythms and the heady perfume of cigars and coffee.

At the end of the street, the Puerta Del Conde, a relic of 17th-century fortifications, leads to the Parque Independencia. Here you will find the Altar de la Patria, the mausoleum of the founding fathers of the country: Duarte, Sanchez, and Mella, authors of the Declaration of Independence. A perpetual flame commemorates the three men responsible for the creation of the Dominican Republic.

Calle El Conde
Santo Domingo 10210

content.title: Hostal Nicolas de Ovando - MGallery by Sofitel : aristocratic elegance

introduction.small: This exotic jewel from the MGallery by Sofitel sits regally on the Calle de las Damas, in the old quarter, near other cool hotels, restaurants, and historical sites.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hostal Nicolas de Ovando - MGallery by Sofitel : aristocratic elegance

paragraphs.text:
This former palace of the governor of the city, comrade of Columbus, dates to 1502. The three lavish original homes, connected by a string of patios with ancient colonnades, were converted into a five-star hotel. Featuring walls of stone, weathered by the centuries, and replete with secret corridors and carved woodwork, this is where the legacy of a prestigious past coexists with vintage curtains and the delicate whispers of fountains. The 101 rooms and suites, which offer views of the river or lush gardens, are decorated with elegant modernity and refinement. Always lively, La Residence, the hotel's restaurant, celebrates French cuisine and Creole flavours. Share a moment of conviviality at Cibao Bar, renowned for the cosy atmosphere of a snooker club and an exceptional menu of vintage rums. The presence of an authentic tabaquero is much appreciated for his expert advice, for novices as well as aficionados of Dominican cigars.

Hostal Nicolas de Ovando - MGallery by Sofitel
Ciudad Colonial
Calle Las Damas
Santo Domingo 10210

+1 809 685 9955

www.hodelpanicolasdeovando.com/en/www.sofitel.com/Santo-Domingo

Rooms: from 7,120 DOP

content.title: Museo de las Casas Reales: former seat of royal institutions

introduction.small: Inaugurated as a museum in 1976 in the presence of Spain's King Juan Carlos I, the most-visited monument in the capital is this former office of the president.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museo de las Casas Reales: former seat of royal institutions

paragraphs.text:
Long before being turned into a museum, these two interlinked buildings with beautiful courtyards both of them imposing examples of classical architecture were the headquarters of the main institutions of the Spanish crown during the 16th century. They harboured the Captaincy General, the Royal Treasury, the Royal Audience, and the first Court of Justice in the New World, which had authority over all the courts of America. The construction of the buildings ended in 1520. The entrance is through the main facade of the building, decorated with the coats of arms of Emperor Charles I of Spain and the island of Hispaniola.

On exhibit are treasures found in Dominican waters tracing the national history of the arrival of the Conquistadors up until 1821, the date of the first independence. The entire Spanish period of the island can be seen through maps, weapons, and objects of all kinds showing the everyday life and customs of the time. A rare and interesting curiosity is an apothecary cabinet with ceramic pots of medicinal plants presented in a rigorous alignment.

El Museo de las Casas Reales
Las Damas
Esq Mercedes
Santo Domingo 10212

+1 809 682 8242

content.title: Catedral Santa Maria de la Encarnacion: heritage of the past

introduction.small: With its coral-and-ochre stone facade, and a pure-silver altar of inestimable value, this cathedral was the first religious building constructed on South American soil.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Catedral Santa Maria de la Encarnacion: heritage of the past

paragraphs.text:
Construction on this place of worship originally began in 1514, when it was built out of clay and palm fronds. The cathedral served as the headquarters of Sir Francis Drake, the English privateer who plundered Santo Domingo during the year 1586. Guides like to show the first chapel, to the right of the altar, where Drake allegedly hung his hammock and cut off the nose of a statue with one fell swoop of his sabre. The building also housed the remains of Christopher Columbus at one point. He had expressed the desire to come to rest here in one of the 14 chapels, though his remains have also been claimed to be in Seville, as well as in the Columbus Lighthouse mausoleum and museum on the island.

The controversy continues, and Santo Domingo and Spain are still competing over the honour of housing the remains of this illustrious explorer. The main gate and the door of the cathedral were restored in 1992 to commemorate the 500th anniversary of Columbus' voyage to America.

Catedral Nuestra Señora de la Encarnación
Calle Isabel La Católica
Santo Domingo 10210

+1 809 682 3848

content.title: The Zona Colonial: a passionate meeting with history

introduction.small: The historical centre of the Dominican capital is not only the most passionate part of the city, but also the most romantic.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Zona Colonial: a passionate meeting with history

paragraphs.text:
The past centuries have not sullied the attractiveness of the island's prestigious past. Cradle of the New World, and the first city built on a grid pattern that became the model for all planners of that time, it attests to both the greatness and the excesses of the Conquistadors. The remarkable palaces and Gothic buildings with Romanesque and Moorish influences are the evidence of the beginning of colonisation.

The centre of the city, a UNESCO World Heritage Site restored according to the finest standards, can successfully move into the third millennium while still preserving its magic and identity. Stroll along picturesque streets and the banks of the Ozama River, and visit the remains of the walls that defended the city to the west. History still seems to inhabit countless treasures in Santo Domingo; include in your itinerary the Parque Colon, El Convento de Los Dominicos, Torre del Homenaje, and the Embassy of France, all of which offer a fine view of the city's Spanish heritage.

Zona Colonial
Santo Domingo 10120

content.title: Samourai : for Japanese food lovers

introduction.small: For 25 years, one of the best Asian restaurants on the island highlights subtleties. Its varied menu includes yakinku, a fusion of Korean and Japanese cuisines.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Samourai : for Japanese food lovers

paragraphs.text:
The owners of Samourai, as well as the brigade of chefs, are all Japanese, which reinforces the legitimacy of the ultra-Zen Tokyo atmosphere.

Here, you will find couples, families, and people on business lunches, all appreciating a menu that emphasizes diversity and freshness throughout, including in its multiple sushi combinations. Made to order, as it should be, lovers of tuna and salmon will appreciate the sushi, maki, and sashimi platters. If meat is your preference, try the tasty chicken with ginger and lemon sauce or opt for the hibachi, with meat and vegetables grilled together, or different meats with teriyaki sauce, all accompanied with rice and a delicious green tea.

You can choose between a table in the dining room or a seat at the friendly counter. Note that Sunday brunch is one of the highlights of the week.

Samouraï
Calle Del Seminario 57
Santo Domingo 10210

+1 809 565 1621

www.samurairestaurante.com (in Spanish only)

Menu: from 1,133 DOP

content.title: The Cigar route: the brown gold of Hispaniola

introduction.small: Since 1994, the Dominican Republic has been ranked the top producer and exporter of hand-rolled cigars in the world, ahead of both Honduras and Cuba.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Cigar route: the brown gold of Hispaniola

paragraphs.text:
In the Cibao valley, around Moca and Santiago de Los Caballeros, close to 180 hectares are dedicated to tobacco plantations. This thriving industry, which employs 150,000 people, produces a staggering 250 million ‘premium' cigars annually. The quality is such that experts deem them able to compete with the most famous Cuban brands, and their aromas and taste tend to be less peppery than their more-celebrated rivals.

You can visit the largest cigar factory in the world at Tabacalera de Garcia, based in La Romana, where Cohiba, Romeo y Julieta, Don Diego, and a host of others are manufactured for export only they are not for sale here. You'll need to head to Tabadom Holding or the Leon Jimenes factory, both in Santiago de Los Caballeros, to buy Davidoffs, AVO, and Griffin's ‘hecho a mano', which are the real thing.

Santiago de Los Caballeros
Province de Santiago

content.title: Calle de las Damas: the first paved street in the New World

introduction.small: A favourite promenade of ladies of the court, one might have seen Maria de Toledo, the Spanish King's niece and spouse of Diego Columbus (son of Christopher) walking here.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Calle de las Damas: the first paved street in the New World

paragraphs.text:
Lined with colonial houses from the rich historical past, the street begins at Plaza de Espana, where the Alcazar de Colon stands. Here time seems to stand still with a thick silence, barely touched by the distant laughter of children playing.

The Ozama fortress and the Nuestra Senora de los Remedios chapel are here, as is the Gothic building from the 16th century where Hernan Cortes prepared his expedition to Mexico (now the French Embassy). Across from the aristocratic Hostal Nicolas de Ovando, with its fabulous brick arcades, one can see the Panteon Nacional, a former Jesuit church, which was successively a tobacco warehouse and theatre before becoming a monument dedicated to the nation. In the central nave hangs a monumental bronze chandelier offered to the former dictator Trujillo by Spain's Generalissimo Franco. Also admire a sundial at the end of the street, flanked by four antique guns, built in 1753 on the orders of Governor Francisco Rubio y Penaranda.

Calle de Las Damas
Santo Domingo 10210

content.title: Billini Hotel: a designer address in the colonial neighbourhood

introduction.small: The most luxurious of the boutique hotels of Santo Domingo welcomes you in a magnificently restored 16th-century Dominican monastery.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Billini Hotel: a designer address in the colonial neighbourhood

paragraphs.text:
Proof of booming tourism, a range of upscale hotels has just opened in the centre of the capital to satisfy a clientele searching for luxurious starred accommodations. The uncontested leader is the Billini Hotel, which exerts a particular fascination for its avant-garde concept, remarkably integrated into its historical walls.

With the rooftop pool hosting jazz concerts, this ultimate urban retreat expresses a nice exercise in style between Renaissance architecture and a very contemporary vision of its interior. The 24 stylish and spacious suites, some with a private Jacuzzi, have designer furniture and are inspired by the colourful aesthetics of the 1970s. A nice selection of cocktails from around the world awaits you in the lounge bar, located on the patio, famous for its festive atmosphere. The fitness room, equipped with latest-generation cardio machines, will please many.

Billini Hotel
Calle Padre Billini 256-258
Santo Domingo 10210

+1 809 338 4040

www.billinihotel.com

Rooms: from 8,450 DOP

content.title: Casa de Campo: rendez-vous of the international jet set

introduction.small: This nature complex, one of the most luxurious in the Caribbean, is spread out across close to 30 hectares. Demanding visitors will be satisfied by the vertiginous sensation of space.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Casa de Campo: rendez-vous of the international jet set

paragraphs.text:
Casa de Campo deserves its status as a cult destination. The development of La Romana, in the direction of Punta Cana, started in the early 20th century. The undisputed star is Casa de Campo, designed by American architect William Cox and inaugurated in 1974. This universe of the ultra-selective vacation, with the exotic look of a pueblo, is almost unique in the world. With reception and service worthy of a great palace, the complex's immense grounds (crossed in carts) include a marina and yacht club, a heliport and tennis courts, polo fields and a riding club, all completed by a five-star hotel and villas of very high standing, available for rent or as a primary residence.

But the international reputation of Casa de Campo was mainly forged on the excellence of its three magnificent golf courses, each with a view over the sea, including the famous Teeth of the Dog, the masterpiece of the American architect Pete Dye, which is a sight to behold for beginners and dedicated golfers alike.

Casa de Campo
Carretera La Romana – Higuey
La Romana 22000

+1 809 523 3333

www.casadecampo.com.do

Rooms: from 11,900 DOP

content.title: Alcazar de Colon: The Governor's Palace

introduction.small: The Calle de las Damas leads you to the Alcazar de Colon, the austere residence of Diego Columbus, Viceroy of the Indies and Governor of Santo Domingo.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Alcazar de Colon: The Governor's Palace

paragraphs.text:
The originality of this palace, built in 1510 on the banks of the Ozama River, lies in the technical prowess of its construction. Walls, doors, and windows in coral stone were assembled with remarkable precision, all without using a single nail. The Gothic and Renaissance architecture also includes some sculpted colonnades inspired by the mudéjar style. The 22 rooms recall the splendour of Hispaniola, colonial Santo Domingo. Reconstituted scenes reveal the interiors as well as the customs and habits of high society between the 14th and 16th centuries.

The museum's remarkable collection consists of about 800 beautifully preserved and authentic pieces, including armour and paintings, tapestries, and dishes, as well as some religious objects that will be of great interest to history buffs. In the evening, the gardens and the palace are framed by centuries old palm trees that are lit from below to emphasize the majesty of the building.

Alcázar de Colón
Plaza de España / Calle Las Damas
Santo Domingo 10212

+1 809 687 5361

content.title: Whale sanctuary: four hours at sea with a whale expert

introduction.small: While many boats offer a promenade at sea in the Samana Bay, opt for the highly educational tours by the Canadian scientist who has been on these waters since 1983.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Whale sanctuary: four hours at sea with a whale expert

paragraphs.text:
This sea trip on the Victoria Marine boat, a major tourist attraction for over 30 years, will let you in on the research and in-depth knowledge of Kim Beddall, whose expertise is indisputable and highly appreciated by visitors. Between December and April every year, 10,000 humpback whales leave the Arctic and come to mate in peace in the warm waters of Samana Bay, a few hours north of Santo Domingo. This impressive tour puts you within metres of cetaceans in full mating season.

On the agenda are sprays of water, jumps, and pirouettes that reveal the entire body of the animal. Beddall identifies the different whales by the distinctive white spots on their fins, a kind of fingerprint used for studying their growth and migrations. She also records their unique songs, ultra-sophisticated communication that is audible hundreds of kilometres away. These songs include a melody and a refrain that are different each season. How do both adults and their offspring memorise it? The mystery is far from being solved…

Whale Samana with Kim Beddall
Dock of Cayo Levantado Island
Santa Barbara de Samana 32000

+1 809 538 2494

www.whalesamana.com

content.title: Cabarete: the windsurfing and kitesurfing capital

introduction.small: On the Amber Coast, in the province of Puerto Plata, this small seaside resort is a paradise for boarding fans.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cabarete: the windsurfing and kitesurfing capital

paragraphs.text:
At this internationally reputed spot, strong trade winds provide ideal conditions for extreme water sports enthusiasts. Indeed, every June, Bozo Beach hosts a round of the Kitesurf World Cup. Cabarete deserves its laurels and its sporty image. With five sailing schools, it also offers a wide range of other activities from surfing to horseback riding, without forgetting scuba diving, canyoning, mountain biking, and paddling.

The village has no shortage of bars, restaurants, and hotels, some providing impeccable comfort. Take the road to Callejon, a small village inland. Here you will encounter the authenticity of Dominican life, through its local cuisine, its zest for life, and its modest homes, where people come from afar to dance merengue and bachata.

Cabarete
Province de Puerto Plata

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Santo Domingo
content.introduction: Santo Domingo enjoys a tropical climate, with temperatures moderated by trade winds. Summers are rather hot and nights are cool in the winter. There are two rainy seasons: the first in May and June, and the second in October and November. March is the driest month of the year.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in Dominican Republic is the Dominican Peso (DOP).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: Santo Domingo Las Américas International Airport
airports.description:
Santo Domingo's Las Américas International Airport is located about 30 kilometres (19 miles) east of the city centre.
  • Two terminals:
    • Terminal A (Air France)
    • Terminal B

Getting from the airport to Santo Domingo and back
  • By car
    • Accessible via Autopista Las Américas.
    • Both short- and long-term parking are available in the parking area opposite the terminals (DOP 40 for up to 30 minutes, DOP 960 per day).
    • Several car rental companies have counters in the arrivals hall.
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available at the ranks outside the arrivals hall, and the official ones have a brown sticker on the windshield. The trip to the city centre costs around DOP 3,000.
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, Internet access (Wi-Fi) available in the airport.
  • Telephone: : +1 809 947 2225 / +1 809 947 2297
  • Website: www.aerodom.com

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Santo Domingo
transportation.description: Getting around Santo Domingo is rather complicated. It is true that the networks of bus and guagua (minibus) routes serve the entire metropolitan area, but they can often be dangerously packed at rush hours. As for the city's Metro, it only travels along a few of the major thoroughfares.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Santo Domingo, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organise your stay.

information.title: Tourist travel guide in Dominican Republic
information.description:
The official website maintained by the Dominican Ministry of Tourism provides a wealth of information on Santo Domingo.

  • Website: www.godominicanrepublic.com

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description: See your doctor before you travel. It is recommended that you obtain insurance covering health care expenses as well as medical evacuation or repatriation before you leave home. Santo Domingo counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
There are no vaccination requirements for visitors to the Dominican Republic.

However, the following vaccines are recommended:

  • booster doses for protection against diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis and polio
  • typhoid, hepatitis A and B

For more information, contact Air France's international vaccination centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: https://www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description:
It is recommended to:

  • avoid eating uncooked food
  • avoid eating raw fruits and vegetables on markets

information.title: Water
information.description: Drinking tap water in Santo Domingo is not recommended. It is prudent to drink bottled mineral water instead.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few basic Spanish phrases that will make your stay in Santo Domingo a little easier:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: ¡ Buenos días ! (morning) / ¡ Buenas tardes ! (afternoon)
What time is it ?: ¿ Que hora es ?

Sorry: Disculpe (to say sorry)
Excuse me: Con permiso (to get past) / ¡ Por favor ! (to get attention).
How much is (…)?: ¿ Cuál es el precio de (…) ? /¿ Cuánto es ?
Where can I find (…)?: ¿ Dónde puedo encontrar (…) ?
Where can I buy (…)?: ¿ Dónde puedo comprar (…) ?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Santo Domingo
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Santo Domingo each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: January 21: Altagracia Day (national holiday)
events.description: The feast day of Our Lady of Altagracia, a name for Mary, the mother of Jesus and the patron saint and protector of the Dominican people, is the most important religious holiday in the country after Christmas. Every year nearly 1 million faithful make the pilgrimage to the cathedral in the southeastern town of Higüey, where Our Lady of Altagracia is believed to have performed a miracle. Those remaining in Santo Domingo fill the city's churches reciting prayers, singing hymns and dancing with great fervour.

events.title: January 26: Duarte Day (national holiday)
events.description: Celebrates the birth on this day in 1813 of Juan Pablo Duarte, one of the three founders of the Dominican Republic, revered as the “father” of Dominican independence from Haiti in 1844. The day is marked with ceremonies at the national pantheon, the Altar de la Patria, where Duarte is buried, profusely decorated with flowers for the occasion.

events.title: Late February: Procigar Festival (local event)
events.description: Held in Santiago, the country's second largest city, known as the “Cigar Capital of the World”, in the eastern city of La Romana and at the resort destination of Punta Cana, this six-day festival attracts cigar aficionados from around the world every year. The programme includes educational seminars and presentations on the industry, tours of tobacco factories, entertainment and leisure activities, plus plenty of opportunities to enjoy some of the world's top-rated cigars.

events.title: February 27: Independence Day (national holiday)
events.description: On this day in 1844, the Dominican Republic gained independence from Haiti, its neighbour, making it the only Latin American country whose commemorations do not mark a break from European colonial rule. Celebrations include not only street parties and military parades, but carnival festivities as well since the day always falls close to the beginning of Lent.

events.title: September 24: Feast of Our Lady of Mercy (Día de Las Mercedes, national holiday)
events.description: Celebrates the Dominican Republic's second patron saint, the Virgen de la Mercedes, who represents the country and the island of Hispaniola as a whole. Numerous religious processions mark this feast every year.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for the Dominican Republic
administrativeProcedures.description:
As a French citizen, you do not need to obtain a visa if you will be visiting the Dominican Republic for less than 90 days. You need only be in possession of a passport valid for at least six months from the date of entry.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Santo Domingo and the Dominican Republic, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the Dominican Republic page of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs’ website: view information for travellers to the Dominican Republic

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: Government Offices
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

banks.title: Banks
banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.

goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Santo Domingo, tipping is not necessarily required, although always appreciated if you are satisfied with the service. It is customary to tip about 10% of the bill in restaurants, bars and cafés.
